awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Active Learning for Out-of-class Activities to Improve Student Success
awd_abstract_narration:
Motivating and engaging students with course content once they leave the classroom is challenging. A plethora of research exists on various in-class student engagement methods. However, there is a dearth of research on keeping students engaged with traditional out-of-class activities. This project will provide Computer Science students interactive and motivating out-of-class activities. Activities will be available in a mobile environment which the current generation of students actively use. They will accommodate personalization and adaptation to optimize the learning experience for each individual student. This approach is expected to motivate students to take personal responsibility for learning. The project is a collaboration between a Hispanic Serving Institution and a Historically Black University. The open source nature of the mobile platform may facilitate its adoption by other disciplines and institutions. The project addresses the national interest in developing a strong and diverse Information Technology workforce. 

The goal of this project is to motivate students to take initiative for learning outside the classroom. Out of class active learning activities will be enhanced with four unique factors. First, the activities are interactive and smaller than traditional out-of-class activities. This allows for instructional scaffolding. The activities can be deployed more frequently and with higher expectations. This is expected to motivate students to raise expectations of themselves. Second, the project's mobile technology-based learning environment will deliver and administer the activities. Third, social networking with their peers is incorporated into the learning environment. Finally, gamification components in the form of online learning and engagement strategies are used to encourage students to participate and become more engaged in the activities. The mobile interactive learning environment allows faculty to facilitate learning even after the students leave the classroom. It allows early intervention when students fall behind their peers. Active out-of-class learning experiences enable learning to occur anytime, anywhere, and at the student's own place. This is expected to promote more effective student engagement, enhanced student learning, improved satisfaction, and increased student retention. The project team includes computer science faculty from two universities that serve unique student population. Through this collaboration, two diverse student populations will be engaged with the intervention. This will allow better insights for generalizing the approach to broader audiences.

por.por_cntn:
Classroom teaching is effective for the initial learning of new content. However, students must spend time outside the classroom to practice the content to build skills and expertise. Such out-of-class activities (e.g., homework and assignments) have been used for a long time to help students develop their expertise. Due to various sociocultural reasons, we have seen a drop in student engagement with out-of-class activities in recent years. Students are working more to offset the rising cost of living. They are also more familiar with mobile app-based systems for communication, entertainment, commerce, etc. To enable students' engagement with out-of-class activities, this project studied gamification and social networking components in designing a mobile educational platform.  

In particular, we explored the role of scaffolding, peer influence, and self-reflection with the mobile app designed to create an active learning environment outside the classroom. The developed app, Dysgu, is available on mobile devices and allows students to see the class status (e.g., the number of students working on the assignment). Due to COVID, the project was delayed by three semesters. After COVID, we deployed the app in early Computer Science classes and studied the effect of Dysgu on student performance for two semesters. 

This project facilitated engaged student learning in two early CS courses. Multiple undergraduate students participated in the research as undergraduate research assistants. Both these factors contributed to workforce development and STEM research. The developed software and related materials are available online. The project also supported the acquisition of physical resources that other classes in the CS department at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) can use. 

Briefly described next are some of the key features of Dysgu and the key findings of our study. Further details are available in our publications. 

Dysgu features:

 (1) The Dysgu system comprises a faculty-side app and a student-side app. Both sides use a cloud-based repository system. Dysgu only uses cloud vendors' free options. The faculty side of Dysgu allows instructors to create modules with interactive activities. These activities or questions are auto-graded. The activities can be placed in modules in learning paths with different degrees of difficulty to support instructional scaffolding. Some paths can be assigned as practice paths, while another path can be treated as a student learning outcome (SLO) path - where students are assessed on their learning skills. Additionally, there can be paths with extra credit activities. These activities have interactive elements, such as multiple screens, multiple user interface components to interact, cause-effect scenarios, etc.

(2) Dysgu includes a few gamification and social networking aspects within student privacy regulations to motivate and engage students. Students can compare their progress with their classmates. Dysgu shows the student score, placement (module, path, exercise-specific) compared to the class, and timing information about problem-solving activities. Additionally, students are awarded badges depending on different conditions (fastest in the class to answer, highest score, etc.), and they can see what badges they won and compare them with the rest of the class. It also shows how many other students have checked their progress, which might encourage the students to engage more in the activities. 

(3) Dysgu is developed to support several adaptations for different class situations and personalization to address student needs. For instance, the student-side app allows students to set the number of notifications they will receive from the app each day. This enables students to change and update their study schedules to manage their classes, work, and other commitments. 

Research findings:

With the help of Dysgu, we studied the impact of scaffolded out-of-class activities on student engagement with out-of-class activities. We collected Dysgu usage data, student performance data, and multiple survey data. Analysis of these data shows that students perform better when using the interactive Dysgu app. The timing of submission also improved with the app, as we saw more students submitting on time or ahead of time. The survey responses showed that students preferred mobile platforms for out-of-class activities; they preferred the ability to personalize the mobile platform (e.g., rate and time of notifications). The grading and timing data clearly show better student performance, which is reinforced by student responses on the experience surveys. All these data strongly point to the potential of mobile educational platforms that integrate peer influence, self-reflection, and scaffolding in keeping students engaged with out-of-class activities.
